investigations.title: CAS Investigation 1 Proportional Reasoning Using Ratio Comparisons

text: In the 6th grade Unit Comparing Quantities, we looked at many situations that involved ratios. Recall that a ratio is a comparison between two quantities. We looked at many comparison situations, for example, Packaging Green and White Cupcakes, Walking Backwards Race, and Sharing Smoothie Bars.
Writing a ratio as 2/3 is called the fraction form of a ratio.
How is this fraction form of a ratio the same as or different from fractions?
Two ratios are equivalent if they express the same comparisons. For example, the ratio of green cupcakes to white cupcakes is the same in the following packages:
2 green cupcakes and 3 white cupcakes
4 green cupcakes and 6 white cupcakes
12 green cupcakes and 18 white cupcakes
What patterns do you see among the comparisons?
In this Unit we will learn more about ratios and reasoning with ratios.

Every year, the 7th grade students at Langston Hughes School go on an outdoor education camping trip. During the week-long trip, the students study nature and participate in recreational activities. Everyone pitches in to help with the cooking and cleanup.

This year, Arvin and Mariah are making orange juice for the campers. They plan to make the juice by mixing water with concentrated liquid orange juice. To find the recipe that tastes best, they decide to test various recipes.
• Which recipe will make juice that is the most “orangey”? Least “orangey”? Explain your reasoning.

Recipe A will make the most orangey juice and Mix C will make the least orangey juice. Students will use part-to-part (concentrate to water) or part-to-whole (concentrate to juice) comparisons. Strategies students might use to conclude the most and least orangey juice:

• Scaling up each ratio to the same number of parts for one of the quantities. This would look very much like “Common Denominator” or “Common Numerator” thinking. (Note: Since these are ratios, there is no denominator or numerator.)
  • Unit Rate. Students might scale each ratio to have one of the quantities equal to 1. For example, 1 concentrate to x water or x concentrate to 1 water.
  • Drawing pictures to show how much water for each cup of concentrate is in each mix. The goal is to partition the water so that each cup of concentrate gets the same amount of water. For example:
Mix A, we have 1 ½ cups of water for each cup of concentrate.
Mix B, we have 1 4/5 cups of water for each cup of concentrate.
Mix C, we have 2 cups of water for each cup of concentrate.
Mix D, we have 1 2/3 cups of water for each cup of concentrate.
Situation A. Mr. Zhoa’s Students’ Strategies
Mr. Zhoa’s class had some interesting strategies for answering the questions about the orange juice recipes which they displayed on posters. Examine the work of each group.

1. Do you agree with the students’ strategies? Can you use the strategy to decide which recipe is the most orangey? Explain.
  2. How are the strategies alike? Different?
Moja's Group
Lima's Group
Tatu's Group
Sanji's Group
All of the groups use strategies that can answer the question of which recipe is the most orangey.
Moja’s Group
Moja’s group scales up each part-to-part recipe to 90 cups of water. Since the water is all the same amount, you can see which one has more concentrate – or is the most orangey.
Lima’s Group

Lima’s group uses a picture to show a part-to-part relationship. They seem to look at how the concentrate is “spread out” over the water. They also show the unit rate of how much water per cup of concentrate. Since you have the same amount of concentrate, you can see which recipe has more water – or is more watered down. Mix A has the least water (1 1/2 ) for the 1 cup of water. So it is the least watered down and will have the strongest orangey taste.
Tatu’s Group
Tatu’s group uses percents of the part-to-whole recipe. The largest percent of concentrate will be the most orangey. Mix A is 40% concentrate.
Sanji’s Group

Sanji’s group uses part-to-whole amounts of the recipes. They scale all of the concentrates to 15. Since there is the same amount of concentrate, you can see which recipe makes the most juice — in other words, where the concentrate is most watered down and thus the least orangey (Mix C). Mix A makes the least amount of juice (37.5 cups) for the 15 cups of concentrate. So it is the juice that contains the must orangey concentrate.
Possible answers about how the strategies are alike and different:
Alike
All use correct strategies that can be used to answer the question.
All of them set one of the quantities equal, so they could compare the amount of the other quantity.
Moja – 90 cups of water
Lima – 1 cup concentrate
Tatu – 100% juice
Sanji – 15 cups of concentrate
Part-to-part ratio was used by Moja and Lima.
Part-to-whole ratio was used by Tatu and Sanji.
Different
All the strategies are slightly different.
Moja scaled up each part-to-part recipe to 90 cups water.
Lima used a picture to show the unit rate of water per cup of concentrate in the part-to-part recipes.
Tatu used percents to get all the juice amounts to 100. Percents are a part-to-whole ratio with 100 as the whole.
Sanji scaled up to 15 parts concentrate per the whole amounts of juice.
Situation B. More Student Strategies
Examine the strategies below and answer the question.
Max’s Strategy
I think that recipes A and C are both the most “orangey” since the difference between the number of cups of water and the number of cups of concentrate is 1. Is Max correct? Explain.
Max’s thinking is incorrect.
He is using additive thinking rather than multiplicative thinking. He subtracted the first quantity from the second quantity.

The recipes are 2 to 3 and 1 to 2. Both quantities in the ratios are 1 apart. However, to determine the orangey-ness, you have to consider the relationship between the two quantities. In Recipe A, you have 2 for every 3. In Recipe C, you have 1 for every 2.

If we think about this as a sharing situation. For example, if you are in a band, you get $2 for every $3 that your band makes. It is not the same as getting $1 for every $2 that you band makes. It is much better to get $2 for every $3.
To help Max see this, we might scale Recipe C to have one of the quantities the same amount. If we think of making batches of Recipe C:
Recipe A Recipe C
2 to 3 1 to 2
Now with the concentrates the same, you can see that the difference between the total quantities is different.
Stella’s Groups Suggestions
Stella’s group suggested rewriting the statements into equivalent statements to make them easier to compare. Different members came up with different statements. Who is correct? Explain.
Stella
3 cups of water to 2 cups of concentrate or
1 cup of water for 2/3 cup of concentrate.
Elise
2 cups of concentrate for 3 cups of water or
1 cup of concentrate for 3/2 cups of water.
Dan
2 cups of concentrate for 5 cups of juice or
1 cup of concentrate for 5/2 cups of juice.
These are all correct unit rates.
Stella used the part-to-part ratio and scaled it down to 1 cup of water.
3 cups of water to 2 cups of concentrate or
1 cup of water for 2/3 cup of concentrate.
Elise used the part-to-part ratio and scaled it down to 1 cup of concentrate.
2 cups of concentrate for 3 cups of water or
1 cup of concentrate for 3/2 cups of water.
Dan used the part-to-whole ratio and scaled it down to 1 cup of concentrate.
2 cups of concentrate for 5 cups of juice or
1 cup of concentrate for 5/2 cups of juice.
Describe some strategies for solving problems that involve ratios.
Answers will vary.
Students may mention scaling ratios to get one quantity equal so you can compare the other quantity.
Unit rates get one of the two quantities to 1, so you can think about the how the other quantity compares.
Ratios can be represented as part-to-part or part-to-whole relationships.
Ratios can be written as statements or percents or drawn as pictures.
In Problem 1.1, students used ratios to determine which recipe was the most “orangey.”
Some students used a part-to-part ratio and others used a part-to-whole ratio. Recall from the Comparing Quantities Unit that:
A part-to-part ratio
2 cups of concentrate to 3 cups of water
2 cups concentrate : 3 cups water
It compares one part (the concentrate) to the other part (the water) in the whole (the juice).
Part-to-whole ratio
2 cups of concentrate to 5 cups of juice
2 cups concentrate : 5 cups juice
It compares one part (the concentrate) to the whole (the juice).
Stella’s group used unit rates. Recall that a unit rate is a specific kind of ratio where one of the quantities being compared is 1 unit. Every ratio has two unit rates.
Stella and Elise used part-to-part comparisons to write unit rates:
3 cups of water to 2 cups of concentrate can be written as
1 cup of water to 2/3 cups of concentrate
or
3/2 cups of water to 1 cup of concentrate.
Dan used part-to-whole comparison to write a unit rate:
2 cups of concentrate for 5 cups of juice can be written as
1 cup of concentrate for 5/2 cups of juice
or
2/5 cup of concentrate for 1 cup of juice
Arvin and Mariah need to make a decision on which recipe to use during camp.
Consider each camper getting a cup of juice. For each of the four recipes, determine:

• How many batches of each recipe are needed to make juice for 210 campers?
  • For each recipe, how much concentrate is needed to make 1 cup of juice? How much water is needed?
  • How much concentrate and how much water are needed to make juice for 210 campers?
Student may use either the number of batches to scale up the recipe (found to answer bullet #1) or the unit rate (found in bullet #2) to answer the question in the 3rd bullet.
Answers below use the number of batches to scale up the recipe.
Students may make sense of this in table format. (It is similar to how they compared making popcorn in Comparing Quantities.)
Situation A. Table and Equation Strategies
Students in Ms. Lopez’s class used different strategies to find the number of recipes needed for 210 campers. Examine each strategy. How are the two strategies the same? Different?
Adia’s Strategy
I used a rate table to find the number of batches of Recipe A to serve 210 campers.
Otis’s Strategy
I used an equation to show how the ratios are equal and to find the number of batches of Recipe A.

They both used equivalent ratios. Otis used the unit rate of 1batch/(5 c.juice) and scaled it directly up to 210 c. juice. Adia used the unit rate of 1batch/(5 c.juice) and scaled it up several times by changing the total number of cups of juice and then scaling up the number of batches until she got to 210 total cups.
Situation B. Cece Makes Lemonade
After the camp, Cece went home and made lemonade for her family. She uses the unit rate of one cup of concentrate to three cups of cold water. She needs 160 ounces of juice.
1. How much concentrate will she need?
2. How much water will she need?
How do the strategies you used in this Problem compare to those used in Problem 1.1?

New to this Problem are the strategies of using a rate table and using a proportion. Both strategies give a way to see the ratios scaled up. The rate table allows you to see many equivalent ratios. The proportion finds a specific equivalent ratio.
In Problem 1.2, Adia and Otis recognized that the comparisons could be represented with ratios. They used scaling to find the number of batches of Recipe A.
Adia used equivalent ratios in a table to show how the original ratio, 1 to 5, was scaled to find the number of batches.

Otis wrote the original ratio and an equivalent ratio in fraction form. He scaled the quantities in the ratio to find the number of batches needed for 210 cups of juice. He wrote the following equation:
This equation showing two ratios that are equal is called a proportion.

When we find equivalent ratios using strategies like Adia’s table or Otis’s equation to answer questions, we are using proportional reasoning. Both strategies involve proportions. Adia’s table shows many proportions. Otis’s equation shows one proportion.

In the Comparing Quantities Unit, we worked with ratios to determine how to share Smoothie Bars. In the Stretching and Shrinking Unit, we worked with ratios to find missing lengths in similar figures. These examples involved proportional reasoning. There are many other situations in which setting up a proportion can help us solve a problem.
For each scenario answer the questions. Explain your reasoning.
Smoothie Bar
Zane is 12 years old and decides to share a Smoothie Bar with his sister Stella, who is 4 years old. He shares it according to the ratio of their ages. The bar is marked into 4 equal segments.
• How would they share the Smoothie Bar?
Reading Speeds
Mitch reads 480 words in 3 minutes.

• How long will it take him to read a book that has 20,000 words?
  • How many words can he read in an hour?
Height of Trees
The triangles in this picture are similar.
• Find the height of the tallest tree.
Student Council Representation
Students at the Mighty Middle School create a student council. The number of students in each grade is:
Grade 6 has 121 students
Grade 7 has 119 students
Grade 8 has 135 students
Each grade will get one representative for every 30 students in the grade.
• How many representatives will each class have?
Grade 6 (1 representative)/(30 students in the grade) = (4.03333… representatives)/(121 students in the grade)
Grade 7 (1 representative)/(30 students in the grade) = (3.966666… representatives)/(119 students in the grade)
Grade 8 (1 representative)/(30 students in the grade) = (4.5 representatives)/(135 students in the grade)
Depending on how the parts of 30 are handled, the grades might get:
Grade 6: 4 Representatives,
Grade 7: 3 or 4 Representatives, and
Grade 8: 4 or 5 Representatives.
Situation A. Writing a Proportion
• Nic wrote the following proportions to solve the first part of Reading Speeds scenario. What are other ways you could write the proportions? Is the answer the same? Explain.
(3 minutes)/(480 words) = (x minutes)/(20,000 words)
(3 minutes)/(x minutes) = (480 words)/(20,000 words)

There are other ways to write the proportion correctly. The answer will be 125 minutes for each proportion. The scale factor is different depending on the relationships shown. It is important to pay attention to which quantities and units you are comparing in the proportion. For example, you would not scale 20,000 words to 3 minutes. Note that some students may mention using the unit rate of 160 words in 1 minute as a way to write the proportions.
• Pick one of the other situations in the Initial Challenge and write it as a proportion.
Smoothie Bar
(12 (Zane^' s age))/(4 (Stella^' sage)) = (3 segments)/(1 segment) OR (12 (Zane^' s age))/(3 segments) = (4 (Stella^' sage))/(1 segment)
Height of Trees
(5 ft.nested triangle.)/(8 ft.nested triangle) = (30 ft.large triangle )/(48 ft.large triangle ) OR (48 ft.large triangle)/(8 ft.nested triangle) = (30 ft.large triangle )/(5 ft.nested triangle.)
Note: With similar triangles, we used two proportions to find similar shapes.
In the beginning of Stretching and Shrinking, we scaled the corresponding sides from an original to an image. We did not write this as a proportion then. But now we can.

In Investigation 4 of Stretching and Shrinking, we looked at the ratio of sides within a triangle and compared it to the corresponding ratios of sides of the image. There we were solving proportions, but not writing them in proportion form.
Student Council Representation

Grade 6 (1 representative)/(30 students in the grade) = (4.03333… representatives)/(121 students in the grade) OR (121 students in the grade)/(30 students in the grade) = (4.03333… representatives)/(1 representative)

Grade 7 (1 representative)/(30 students in the grade) = (3.966666… representatives)/(119 students in the grade) OR (119 students in the grade)/(30 students in the grade) = (3.9666… representatives)/(1 representative)

Grade 8 (30 students in the grade )/(1 representative) = (135 students in the grade)/(4.5 representatives) OR (30 students in the grade )/(135 students in the grade) = (1 representative)/(4.5 representatives)
Situation B. Taren’s Reasoning
In the Height of Trees scenario, Taren’s reasoning is shown below. Is Taren correct? Explain.
Taren’s Reasoning
The scale factor from the small triangle to large triangle is 6.
To find the height of the tallest tree I multiplied the corresponding length, 5ft, by the scale factor. The height of the tree is 30 feet.
Yes. When you match up corresponding sides the scale factor will be 6:
Situation C. Fair Representation

The 7th and 8th grade students at the Mighty Middle School claimed that the assignment of representation was not fair. Do you agree? If yes, explain why. If not, describe a fairer method to assign delegates.
This is an opinion of how students interpret the designation of delegates or how they deal with rounding.
7th grade may say it is not fair since Grade 6 has only 2 more students, but they might get one more representative.
8th grade may say it is not fair since Grade 7 has 16 fewer students, but they may get the same number of representatives.
How are proportions like other strategies that you have used to solve ratio problems? How are they different?
Alike:

• Proportions scale ratios like other strategies.
  • Like other strategies, proportions help you answer questions
Different:

• Proportions are an equation.
  • With some strategies, you get many equivalent ratios. With proportions, you get a specific equivalent ratio.
  • Proportions are written in fraction form.

investigations.title: CAS Investigation 2 Proportional Reasoning Using Rate Comparisons

text: In Investigation 1, we explored strategies for comparing quantities. We used ratios, scaling, proportions, percents, and differences. Knowing several methods of comparison is not enough. We also need to be able to recognize when a situation is proportional and which method of comparison is appropriate to solve the problem.
Consider the following comparisons:
We need two sandwiches for each person at the picnic
I earn $5.50 per hour when I babysit for my neighbor.
A 6-piece serving of chicken nuggets will provide 18 grams of protein.
Akira's top running rate is 8.5 kilometers per hour.
What is being compared in each statement above?
What is the unit of measure for each quantity?
Each statement can be written as a ratio, such as,
5.5 dollars to 1 hour
or
18 grams of protein for every 6 pieces of chicken nuggets
Since each ratio is a comparison of two quantities measured in different units, they are called rates.

The dining room at a camp has two sizes of tables. A large table seats ten people, and a small table seats eight people. When the campers come for dinner one night, there are four pizzas on each large table and three pizzas on each small table. The campers at each table share the pizzas equally.
• Does a person sitting at a small table get the same amount of pizza as a person sitting at a large table? Explain your reasoning and conclusion.
No. Possible strategies include scaling up or down.
Possible explanation scaling up to 40 people:
Large Table
4 pizzas for every 10 people (4 : 10) is equivalent to
16 pizzas for every 40 people (16 : 40)
Small Table
3 pizzas for every 8 people (3 : 8) is equivalent to
15 pizzas for every 40 people (15 : 40).
Therefore, a person sitting at the large table gets more pizza since 16 pizzas for 40 people is greater than 15 pizzas for 40 people.
Possible explanation scaling up to 12 pizzas:
Students might make equivalent ratios with the same number of pizzas, for example,
Large
4 pizzas for every 10 people
12 pizzas : 30 people
Small
3 pizzas for every 8 people
12 pizzas : 32 people
If more people share the same number of pizzas, each person gets a smaller share.
Possible explanation scaling down to one person (unit rate of amount of pizza per person):
Large
4 pizzas for every 10 people
Each gets 4/10 or 0.4 of a pizza per person
Small
3 pizzas for every 8 people
Each gets 3/8 or 0.375 of a pizza per person
Therefore, each person at a large table will get more pizza than each person at a small table.
Possible explanation scaling down to one people per pizza ( unit rate of amount people per pizza):
Large
4 pizzas for every 10 people
21/2 people per pizza
Small
3 pizzas for every 8 people
22/3 people per pizza
Therefore, each person at a large table will get more pizza than each person at a small table.
Situation A. Three Strategies
Selma, Tony, and Terry came up with different ways to solve the problem. Who is correct? Explain.
Selma’s Strategy
For each table, I found the amount of pizza each person would get.
Large Table
4 pizzas for 10 people =
Tony’s Strategy
For each table, I found the number of people that would share one pizza.
Large Table
10 people for every 4 pizzas =
Terry’s Strategy
For the large table, there are 10 people for 4 pizzas. The difference is 6.
For the small table there are 8 people for 3 pizzas. The difference is 5.
4/10 pizza for 1 person
Small Table
3 pizzas for 8 people =
3/8 pizza for 1 person
The people at the large table get more pizza.
(x people for every 1 pizza = )
2.5 people for every 1 pizza
Small Table
8 people for every 3 pizzas =
x people for every 1 pizza =
2 2/3 people for every 1 pizza
The people at the small table get more pizza since 2 2/3 or 2.666…is greater than 2.5.
Large Table
10 people - 4 pizzas = 6
Small Table
8 people - 3 pizzas = 5
So, the people at the small table get more pizza.
Selma is correct. (10 people)/(4 pizzas) = (1 person)/(4/10 pizza)
(8 people)/(3 pizzas) = (1 person)/(3/8 pizza)
Tony scales the ratio correctly. (10 people)/(4 pizzas ) = (2.5 people)/(1 pizza)
(8 people)/(3 pizzas) = (2 2/3 people)/(1 pizza)
But Tony does not correctly interpret the numbers. 2 2/3 is greater than 2.5. But that means that more people are sharing a pizza at the small table.
Terry is not correct.
The difference does not have a meaning. It is not meaningful to subtract pizza from people.

Even though there are six more people than pizzas at the large table and only five more people than pizzas at the small table, each person at the large table will get a greater share of pizza than each person at the small table.

Note: Some students might agree with Terry. For them, the comparison implied by a ratio is defined by the difference between the ratio parts. They think about how many extra people there are compared to the number of pizzas (six at the large table and five at the small table).
Situation B. Pizza for all the Campers
If there are 210 campers, how many pizzas are needed
• If only large tables are used?
Proportions as a Strategy
10 people = 210 people
4 pizzas = 84 pizzas
Unit Rate as a Strategy

A way to find missing values in a proportional situation is to build a rate table of equivalent ratios using the unit rate. Some students will notice that even though the math is correct, 5/2 of a person is not possible.
Unit Rate as a Strategy
• If only small tables are used?
8 people = 210 people
3 pizzas = 78.75 pizzas
Unit Rate as a Strategy
A way to find missing values in a proportional situation is to build a rate table of equivalent ratios using the unit rate.
Situation C. Considering Extra-large Tables
The camp decides to use only extra-large tables that seat 25 people.
• How many pizzas should be put on an extra-large table?
Answers will vary. If students use the same unit rate that was at the large table, they may solve it with a proportion and scale factor.
• (10 people)/(4 pizzas) =(1 person)/(4/10 pizza) = (25 people)/(10 pizzas)

Students may create a different ratio for an extra-large table. One example from a classroom was from a group that wanted the amount of pizza per person at the extra-large table to be more than at the large table. They found that 25 people and 10 pizzas was the exact same amount per person, so they said if you put 11 pizzas it would be more than 4/10 per person. They showed it with this proportion:
• (25 people)/(11 pizzas) = (1 person )/(44/100 pizza)
• How many pizzas would be used to serve 210 campers if they sit at extra-large tables?
If students use the ratio from Situation C #1 it would be
(25 people)/(10 pizzas)= (210 campers)/(84 pizzas)
Or if they used (25 people)/(11 pizzas) = (210 campers)/(92.4 pizzas) (In classrooms that used this idea most students said 93 pizzas.)
We have used several strategies for solving problems that involve ratios. How do you decide which method to use?
Answers will vary.
Some students will have a preferred strategy that they always use. Other students will decide based on the quantities given in the ratio and what they need to scale to.
Students may mention:
Writing the ratio in words and scaling up to equivalent ratios, using rate/ratio tables, writing proportions, and using percents (although students might not bring up percents until Investigation 3.)

problems.title: CAS 2.2 Comparing Pizza Prices
problems.subtitle: How Do We Know It Is Proportional?

text: Julia is in charge of ordering pizzas for a camp dinner. There are two pizza companies nearby. Both allow customers to use the same pricing rate for fewer or more pizzas than the listed number.
Julia wonders which company to use. The cost is a deciding factor. She uses tables to determine the cost of the pizzas.

columns.name: Total Cost of Pizza in Dollars

text: • On a copy of the tables, fill in the total costs for each number of pizzas shown.
• How can Julia use the tables to make her choice? Which company should she choose and why?

content.name: Pizza Price of Royal Pizza- Solution

text: Students might work the table forward or backwards looking for equivalent ratios to fill in the table. Some students might start with 5 for $65 then find 10 for $130 and 20 for $260, etc. Some students may find how much it is for 1 pizza and then use that to scale up and fill in the rest of the table.

content.name: Pizza Prices for Howdys Pizza- Solution

text: Students need to recognize that the $195 for 15 pizzas also includes the $30 delivery charge. They need to subtract that and then use the $165 to either scale up or down to find the other values in the table.
Some students may create another row to the table to find the cost of the pizzas without delivery.

Some students won’t find the exact amount but they will notice that for 15 pizzas it is the same cost for each company. After 15 pizzas, the price at Howdy’s Pizza is always cheaper than Royal Pizza. Since 84 pizzas (which is the needed number of pizzas from the previous problem) is more than 15 pizzas, Howdy’s Pizza will be cheaper.

At Royal Pizza the price for 210 campers or 84 pizzas is $1,092. Students might use the unit rate and then find the cost with $13 x 84= $1,092. Students might also use values on the table to add up to 84 pizzas: one example is 20 pizzas are $260 and 4 groups of that would be 80 pizzas for $1,040 then we need 4 more pizzas, which are $52. So, $1,040 + $52 = $1,092.

At Howdy’s Pizza the price for 210 campers or 84 pizzas is $954. Students need to find that the price of the pizzas is $11 each and then add a $30 delivery charge. So for 84 pizzas it would be $84 x 11 = $924, then add the delivery charge: $924 + 30 = $954.
Situation A. Another Three Strategies
Students in Ms. Bennett’s classroom used a variety of strategies to determine the price of pizzas. Examine each strategy. Are they correct? Explain why or why not.
Amit’s Strategy
I saw that at Royal, 5 pizzas cost $65. I wanted to compare the prices for 5 pizzas at each restaurant. So, I scaled down the pizza and price at Howdy’s by dividing each quantity by 3.
Amit’s strategy is not correct. He forgot that part of the $195 is the $30 delivery charge. He needs to subtract the delivery charge before he scales the pizzas.
Eun Mi’s Strategy

I tried to use proportions, but that did not work. So, I used a graph to determine the costs. I noticed that the graph of Howdy’s Pizza did not go through the origin. I wonder if that is why proportions did not work.

Eun Mi is correct. The costs for Howdy’s Pizza is not proportional. We can take two points from Royal Pizza and write a proportion. We cannot take two points from the graph of Howdy’s and write a proportion.

The graph of Howdy’s Pizza costs does not go through (0,0). Proportional situations will have graphs that go through the origin. Also, with a proportional situation, the point (1, ?) will identify the unit rate.

Note: These graphs relate to the Stretching and Shrinking Problem 2.2 about Mug Hats. Students saw that adding to the rules moved the hats. It did not stretch or shrink them. Adding does not create similar figures because similarity is proportional, which means it is multiplicative.
Here, adding the $30 delivery fee slides the line up.
If we removed the $30 delivery fee, the graph would slide down. (See the red points.) And the costs would be proportional 1/11= 2/22= 10/110.
Note: In the next Unit, we will revisit both proportional and non-proportional graphs.
Meredith’s Strategy
I found the unit rate of the cost for one pizza for each company. Then I scaled up to find the total cost for pizzas.
However, with Howdy’s, after finding the cost of one pizza, I had to add the $30 delivery charge.
Meredith’s strategy is correct.
To find the unit rate for Howdy’s, the delivery charge must be removed.
Mary’s Strategy
I used the unit rate to write equations.
C is the total cost of the pizza and n is the number of pizzas.
For Royal: CR = 13n
For Howdy’s: CH = 11n and then added $30 for delivery
Mary’s strategy is correct.
The unit rate is shown as the multiplier (coefficient). At Royal’s for 1 pizza, you pay $13.
Note: This is an introduction to an equation that is not proportional. In the next Unit, we will look more closely at both proportional and non-proportional equations.
How can you determine if a situation is proportional?
Possible answer:
We have seen proportional situations in Royal’s Pizza, Sharing Pizzas at the Tables, the Orange Juice Recipes, and with similar figures.
A proportional situation is multiplicative. It involves using factors or multiples of the quantities in a ratio.
With proportional situations, we can:

• Scale ratios by multiplying or dividing both quantities to find equivalent ratios.
  • Show the equivalent ratios in many ways including tables and proportions.
  • Use the unit rate to write equations, like Mary did for Royal’s, CR = 13n.
  • Make graphs that go through the origin.

problems.title: CAS 2.3 Finding Costs
problems.subtitle: Unit Rates and the Constant of Proportionality

text: In a proportional relationship the multiplicative relationship between the quantities is always the same. The unit rate or constant of proportionality tells us about the multiplicative relationship between the two quantities. The unit rate for the cost of one pizza at Royal’s is $13.
For example,
5 pizzas for $65
or
1 pizza for $13
or
Cost C for N pizzas is 13N
or

The equation C = 13N relates cost of pizza and number of pizzas. This equation represents a proportional relationship because we multiply one variable by a constant number to get the value of the other variable.
13 is the unit rate or constant of proportionality
What is the other constant of proportionality? Is it useful in this situation?
In this Problem we will look at tables, equations, and graphs of proportional relationships.
Foodfresh has oranges on sale at 10 for $2. Mia represents the sale with a table, proportions, equations, and graphs.
• Is each representation correct? Explain.

Yes. Each one accurately represents the cost for buying different amounts of oranges. The proportion, equation, and graph on the left show how many oranges you get for different increments of 20¢. The proportion, equation, and graph on the right show the cost for different numbers of oranges.
There is only one table, because both unit rates can be shown on the table.
• What does each representation tell you about the rate?
On the table, we see the unit rate when one of the quantities is 1.
In the proportions, we can scale the rate, so one of the quantities is 1.
In the equations, the multiplier (coefficient) is the unit rate.
In the graph, we can find the unit rate by finding the point where x = 1, y = unit rate. Or we can look at how much the graph increases for every increment of 1.
• How is the constant of proportionality represented in each representation
The same way the rate is represented. In a proportional situation, the unit rate and constant of proportionality are the same thing.
Situation A. Buying Tickets
Noralie is buying tickets for a concert online. The cost of the tickets is represented in a table, graph, and equation.
C is the cost of the tickets
N is the number of tickets
• How is the constant of proportionality (or unit rate) represented in each?
The constant of proportionality is represented:
In the table when one quantity is 1.
In the graph by the amount of increase in the total cost (y value) each time the number of tickets (x value) increases by 1.
In the equation by the number being multiplied by N (number of tickets).
• How does this information help us answer questions about proportional situations?
If we know one of the quantities is 1, we can scale to any amount to answer a question.
• How many tickets could you buy for $120. How did you determine your answer?
(4,120) or 4 tickets.
To find the number of tickets, see blue notations on the representations above.
With the table, scale the $30 up to $120.
With the graph, find the point (x, 120).
With the equation we can substitute 120 for C and then solve for the number of tickets.

Note: Students have not worked on formal strategies for solving equations at this point. They will use strategies on their knowledge of operations and/or fact families to solve the problem. For example, they may say that the equation is asking them to find what number (N) times 30 will result in the product of 120. So, they need to use division: 120 ÷ 30 = N, so N =4. This will be developed further in Moving Straight Ahead.
• The concert organizers decide to add processing fee of $10. How does this affect the representations? Is this still a proportional situation? Explain.
It is no longer proportional if you add in a processing fee.
See the change in red to the representations below.
Table – $10 is added to the cost
Graph – the line slides up 10
Equation – the $10 is added to the cost

content.name: Cost of Ticket from the Box Office

text: C is cost of the tickets
N is the number of tickets
Note that 0 tickets for $10 does not make sense in the real world.
Situation B. Using the Constant of Proportionality: Best Buy for Pasta
Mia is shopping for pasta. She sees two advertisements:
Little Giant Store
7 boxes of pasta for $6
Foodfresh Store
6 boxes of pasta for $5
She claims that she can use the constant of proportionality to decide which store has the better price. Is she correct? Explain.
Yes. The constant of proportionality is the same as the unit rate. It will tell you how the prices relate when one of the quantities is 1.
Little Giant Store
7 boxes of pasta for $6
1 box of pasta about $0.86
OR
For $1 you get about 1.16 boxes
Foodfresh Store
6 boxes of pasta for $5
1 box of pasta about $0.83
OR
For $1 you get about 1.2 boxes

Describe how you can determine a unit rate, or constant of proportionality, in a description, rate table, equation, or graph. In what ways is a unit rate or the constant of proportionality helpful for solving a problem?
The constant of proportionality or unit rate is represented:
In a description as a ratio when one of the quantities is 1.
In the table when one quantity is 1.
In the graph by the amount of increase in the cost (y value) each time the number of tickets (x value) increases by 1. It is also at the point (1, ?).
In the equation by the number being multiplied by N (number of tickets).
Knowing both quantities when one quantity in a ratio is equal to 1 makes it easy to scale the ratio. So, this makes it helpful to answer questions.

investigations.title: CAS Investigation 3 Pulling it all Together: Ratios, Rates, and Percents

text: In the Comparing Quantities Unit, we looked at proportional situations that involved percents. We also used percents to solve some of the problems in this Unit, for example, Problem 1.1 Mixing Juice.

Recall that if a part-to-whole ratio can be scaled so that the whole is 100, then the ratio is a percent. The word percent means “out of 100.” We used percent to investigate survey results, test scores, and the number of people most likely to have dimples. Representing ratios or comparisons as percents is also useful in other situations. Percentages can help us with comparisons because we have the same size whole.

When we buy something in a store, we often pay sales tax on the purchase price. For the sales tax, we might see percents such as 5%, 6.2%, or 8%. These are the rates by which the sales price is increased.

A sales tax of 6% means that for every dollar an item costs, a person needs to pay an additional 6 cents. That is, 6 cents for every 100 cents of an item purchased, or $0.06 for every dollar, is added to the cost. This is tax money collected by states. For example, with 6% tax:
Item purchased for $1.00
Sales tax is 6% of $1.00 or $0.06
Total cost $1.06
Note: When a percent calculation for sales tax does not come out to a whole number of cents, the standard practice is to round up the tax to the next penny.
Understanding how to compute and use percents can make us smarter consumers.

Skylar picked up several items he needed for school. He had $25 in cash. As he was nearing the checkout counter he wondered if he had enough cash to pay the bill. The sales tax is 5%. In the basket he has:
Notepad: $8.95
Markers: $6.75
Pencils: $3.80
Sticky notes: $4.25
• What is a good estimate for the total cost of the four items?
Answers will vary.
Notepad ~ $9
Markers~ $7
Pencils ~4
Sticky Notes ~4
• What is a good estimate for the total bill with tax?
Answers will vary.
Using the above estimate of $24, many students will find 5% of 24 and then add that amount into the original $24.
• Does Skylar have enough money? Explain your reasoning.
Answers will vary.

Using the above estimates students might say yes because we overestimated most of the prices and with our estimate being only $0.20 over the $25, he should have enough money. Others might say no because our estimate is over the $25. Students should be able to describe how they estimated and whether they used overestimates or underestimates.
Situation A. Student Strategies
After working on the Initial Challenge, students in Mr. Gomez’s class used various strategies.
Examine each strategy. Which ones are correct? Explain.
Possible Answers:
All of the strategies are correct.
Casey’s Strategy
To compute the total cost of an item that costs $8.95 with a 5% sales tax, I multiply $8.95 by 0.05 and then add the tax to the $8.95.
Casey is using the Distributive Property finding the cost • the % tax + the cost • 100%.
Casey is using the Distributive Property finding the cost • the % tax + the cost • 100%.
Sammi’s Strategy
Multiply $8.95 by 1.05.
That will get the whole amount (100% or 1) and the tax (5% or 0.05).
Sammi is using a proportion to scale from 100% to 105% to find the price with tax included.
Vanessa’s Strategy
I used the Distributive Property. I think this strategy will work for any bill.
or
1.05 • 8.95 to find the total bill.
Vanessa is using a combination of what Casey and Sammi do. Vanessa uses the Distributive Property which results in multiplying by 1.05 (like Sammi did).
Alex’s Strategy
I first find 1%. Then I can find any percent, like the 105% needed for this question.
Alex scales the ratio down to find the unit rate (the amount of money for 1%). Then he scales the rate up to 105 to find the amount of money for 105%.
Ash’s Strategy
I used a percent bar or tape diagram. Extend the bar to find 105%.

Ash uses a percent bar/tape diagram. (Students learned this strategy in Comparing Quantities.) Ash extends the bar past the 100% mark to find the 105% mark. Using the amount of money for 1%, Ash can scale up to 105%. This is like Alex’s strategy with a different representation – a bar diagram rather than a proportion.

Ash uses a percent bar/tape diagram. (Students learned this strategy in Comparing Quantities.) Ash extends the bar past the 100% mark to find the 105% mark. Using the amount of money for 1%, Ash can scale up to 105%. This is like Alex’s strategy with a different representation – a bar diagram rather than a proportion.
Situation B. Student Wonderings
Below are students’ discussions about percents and ratios. Examine each discussion.
Who is correct? Explain.
Sam and Will
Sam says that percents are a lot like fractions.
Will disagrees. He said that percents are more like ratios.
Nicky and Marta
Depending on what strategy you use, Nicky thinks that you can get two different answers when finding the tax on multiple items.
First Strategy: Find the cost of each item with the tax. Then add to find the total price. For example:
= one total price
Second Strategy: Add up the prices of each individual item.
Then find the tax and total.
$9 + $7 + $4 + $4 = total amount for all the items
Total amount for all the items + 5% tax = a different total price
Marta disagrees with Nicky. She claims the answers are the same because of the Distributive Property. And the total prices are the same.
This discussion holds a subtle point that should be discussed with your students.
Percents are rates. Fractions are numbers.

But we use fractions or decimals to compute with percents. Sam is thinking of the fraction form and the way that the ratios/rates scale like finding equivalent fractions. Percents are a ratio because they compare two quantities – some number to 100 with 100 representing one whole.
Marta is correct. For example, when the sales tax is 5%:
For each of these numbers when you multiply by 1.05 that is the price plus the tax that Nicky describes above.
Situation C. Working Backward

Funda bought a used gaming system. She does not remember the price before tax. She does know that the 6% sales tax came to $4.80. What was the price of the used gaming system before tax? How do you know?
Students might also use a percent bar. If the original price is 100% and 6% is $4.80, the percent bar would be divided into equal groups and when those are all totaled it would be $80.
How are percent problems like ratio and rate problems?
Possible answers:
Percent problems are proportional reasoning problems, just like ratios and rates are.
Percents are a new representation of a part to ratio.
Percent problems require finding equivalent ratios and/or scaling up quantities, just like ratio and rates.
Percents set one of the quantities equal, so we can think about the size of the other quantity. So, in some ways, they act like a unit rate does.
At most restaurants, customers pay their server a tip for providing good service. A typical tip is 15% to 20% of the price of the meal.
What is the tip on a restaurant bill of $14?
Mr. Gomez’s class will stop at Larry’s Lunch Place on their field trip. He gives the class a menu so that they can anticipate the cost of their lunch ahead of the trip.
In your group use the menu to make up a lunch order. Write a list of all the items ordered by your group.

• Find the total bill for food including the 6% sales tax for your group.
  • How much will you leave as a tip (between 15% and 20% of the total bill)?
  • Your group members will share the cost of the meal equally. What is each person’s share of the cost, including tip?

Answers will vary. Look for how the students find the total bill: Do they add up all the original prices and then put in the sales tax? Do they find the 6% sales tax on each item and then find the total?
How are they using the 6%: Do they multiply an amount by $0.06 and then add it onto the original price? Do they multiply by 1.06? Do they create percent bars? Do they use proportions?
How did the students decide the total after the tip? Did they use percent bars? Did they use multiplication?
How did the students find the cost for each person? Did they find the total with tax and tip and then divide? Did they find each portion of the costs, divide those, and then add those quotients?
Note: Students may use strategies that are unique. A CMP student in the past said, “Multiply the 6% tax amount by 3 to get an approximation for an 18% tip.”
Situation A. Benchmarks
Many people use benchmarks for determining tips.
Gil explains his strategy: “I always figure out 10% of the bill, and then I use this information to calculate a 15% or 20% tip.”
• Explain why Gil’s method works.
Once you find 10% you can take that amount and divide it in half to get 5%. Add together the amount for 10% and 5% and you will have the 15% tip.
Once you have 10% you can take that amount and double it to get the amount for a 20% tip.
• Use his method to compute a 15% tip and a 20% tip if the final bill is:
Final Bill of $24.50
Final Bill of $17.35
5% would be about $1.23
5% would be $0.87
Situation B. Working Backward
A customer left Jerome $2.50 as a tip for service. That tip is 20% of the total bill for the food.
How much is the food bill? Explain your reasoning.
20% of the original price is $2.50
0.20 x original price = $2.50
Find how many 0.20 are in $2.50
OR
x 5
x5
Situation C. Another Meal at Larry’s
Sandy has a 10% discount off the total price before tax is added for Larry’s Lunch Place. If the cost of the meal is $18.50,
• What is the cost of the meal after the discount?
• What is the total cost with a 6% tax and a 15% tip?
$16.65 x $0.06 = ~$1.00 (amount of sales tax)
$16.65 + $1.00 = $17.75 (amount of bill with sales tax)
Situation D. Discount After Discount
Aladar has a 20% discount coupon to buy new headphones priced at $95. When he got to the telecom store, he learned that they were having a 30% off sale.
The clerk calculated the 30% discount first and then applied the 20% off coupon to the discounted amount.
• What should be the final price (without sales tax)?
$95 - $28.50 = $66.50 (Subtract the 30% discount from the headphone price)
20% of $66.50 is $13.30 (20% discount off the discounted price)
$66.50 - $13.30 = $53.20 (Subtract the 20% discount off the discounted price)
Note: Students might find the discounts each time by finding it in groups of 10% and subtracting those.
• Is that final price the same as a 50% discount? Explain.
No

Note: Some students might answer this without doing the calculation. They might reason that it would be a bigger discount if you took 50% of the $95 because the total is more so the discount you’d subtract would be greater.
OR

With the way that the clerk did the discount (which is the typical way to do it), 30% is taken off of the total price, then 20% is taken off of the discounted price, not the whole price. So, in this case, the total changes. You begin with the whole total, then you reduce it to a discounted total.
If you take 50% off, you would be taking the discount on the total amount.
Describe some strategies you used to solve percent problems.
Strategies will vary.
Students might use percent bar/tape diagrams, proportions, tables with equivalent percentage amounts, multiplying by the fraction, or decimal form of the percent.
Students should mention that you scale percents like you do with other proportional relationships.

problems.title: CAS 3.3 Free Throws and Feeding Chimps
problems.subtitle: The Percent Connection

text: So far in our exploration of proportional reasoning over the past two years, we have become familiar with deciding which problems represent proportional situations and developing a variety of strategies for solving these problems. In this Investigation we have worked with percents as rates. In this Problem we will explore percent problems that do not involve money.

Ming works at the zoo. She mixes food for the chimpanzees. Ming mixes up large batches of food from sacks of high fiber food and sacks of high protein food. She uses a standard scoop and the following recipes.
Ming asks a group of visiting middle school students to help her figure out the quantities she needs to mix for the baby chimps.
• The recipe calls for 40% high fiber and 60% high protein. She needs a total of 225 scoops altogether. How many scoops of each should she use?
OR
60% of high protein 🡲 0.60 x 225 = 135 scoops
40% of high fiber 🡲 0.40 x 225 = 90 scoops
After mixing the baby chimp food, Ming only has 30 scoops of high protein food left.
• She knows that high protein food has to be 40% of the adult chimp mix total. What is the total amount of food she can prepare for the adult chimps?
÷40 ⃕ x30 ⃕
40 High Fiber              1 Scoop                 30 Scoops
100 total                   2.5 Scoops             75 Scoops
÷40 ⤻ x30 ⤻
OR
0.40 x total amount of food = 30 scoops
Situation A. Baby Chimp Recipes
Some students in Ms. Stewart’s class used unit rates to prepare the recipes for the baby chimp recipe. Examine each strategy and then answer the question.
Ahmed’s Strategy: A Table
How will the unit rate in the table help Ming mix up any amount she wants?
Ahmed’s Strategy
When he has the unit rate, he can then scale that up using multiplication when he knows the total amount needed.
Michelle’s Strategy: Equations
She writes two equations.

1. relating the Total amount of food to the amount of Protein, and
  2. relating the Total amount of food to the amount of Fiber.
What equations did she write? How do these equations use unit rates?
Michelle’s Strategy
0.4 x total amount of food = amount of high fiber
0.6 x total amount of food = amount of high protein
The unit rates are what is multiplied by the total amount of food in each equation
Concetta’s Strategy: Graphs
Concetta used two graphs to show the relationships.
Relationship between the Total Amount of Food and the Amount of Protein
Relationship between the Total Amount of Food and the Amount of Fiber
How do the graphs show the unit rate? How do they help Ming mix up any amount she needs?
Concetta’s Strategy

The unit rates show up on the graph in that each time the x value (amount of food) increases by 1 the y value (amount of high protein or high fiber) increases by the unit rate. Concetta could use her graph by finding the total number of cups of food needed on the x and then find the total amount of high fiber or high protein by finding the corresponding y value.
Situation B. Adult Chimp Recipes
Some students in Ms. Stewart’s class used the following strategies to prepare adult chimp recipes. Examine each strategy. Explain how they make sense.
Sze’s Strategy
He says you can use a proportion.
He wrote:
(x scoops of high fiber)/(30 scoops of high protein )= (60%)/(40%)
or
(T scoops of total mix)/(30 scoops of high protein )= (100%)/(40%)
He says you can use either proportion.
Sze’s Strategy
Sze is looking at the ratios in two ways as a percent ratio or as a scoops ratio. His way of thinking about it is similar to the rate table that Ahmed used.
Emily’s Strategy
She uses a graph for mixing the Adult Chimp Recipe.
She says you just have to find the point you need on the graph.
Emily’s Strategy
The point on the graph tells you the total amount of food and the cups of protein. Then you can subtract those amounts to get the cups of fiber.
For example (15,6):
The 15 is the total amount of food.
The 6 is the number of cups that are protein. 15 – 6 = 9 which would be the number of cups of fiber that are needed.
Situation C. Population Growth

Chimpanzees are an endangered species. They are extinct in several of their original countries. They are extensively studied in biomedical research to gain an understanding of various diseases that result in substantial sickness.

A research team was recording the growth of chimpanzees in two remote areas. In one year, the population in Area Amber grew from 15 to 19 chimpanzees. The population in Area Blue grew from 11 to 16 chimpanzees. Which area has the greatest growth in one year? Explain why.
Area Amber grew from 15 to 19
The increase is 4 chimpanzees for every 15.
About 26% increase.
Area Blue grew from 11 to 16 chimpanzees
The increase is 11chimpanzees for every 16.
68.75% increase
This is a greater growth.
How are percents useful to solve problems?
Percents are ratios/rates where one of the quantities in the comparison is equal to 100. Because one of the quantities is the same, it allows you to easily compare two different percents.
Percents also give us a way to discuss and solve problems that involve tax, tip, markups, and changes in something like population.
Did you know?
Chimpanzee, gorillas, orangutans, and bonobos are types of apes.
Wild chimpanzees live only in Africa.
Biologically, chimpanzees are more closely related to humans than they are to gorillas. We share about 95% – 98% of the same DNA.
Chimpanzees make and use tools. For a long time, scientists thought human beings were the only ones who made tools. Other animals make tools, too.
Chimpanzees in captivity have been taught sign language. Washoe, a female chimp, knew more than 240 signs.
Chimpanzees are omnivores. They eat fruits, nuts, seeds, flowers, leaves, and many types of insects. They sometimes hunt and eat small mammals.
Chimpanzees laugh. And, when frightened or angry, their hair will stand on its end.
An adult chimpanzees have 5 or 6 times the strength of a human.
Baby chimpanzees receive 24-hour attention from their mothers. The mothers will sleep with one hand on the baby to keep in constant contact.
Information from: https://www.janegoodall.org.uk/
Did You Know?

The average household's leaks can account for nearly 10,000 gallons of water wasted every year and ten percent of homes have leaks that waste 90 gallons or more per day. Common types of leaks found in the home are worn toilet flappers, dripping faucets, and other leaking valves.
https://www.epa.gov/watersense/fix-leak-week
In this experiment we will simulate a leaking faucet and collect data about the volume of water lost at five-second intervals. We will use our results to make predictions.
Equipment

• A timer, such as a watch, clock with a second hand, or smart phone
  • A Styrofoam or paper cup
  • A paper clip
  • A clear measuring container that measures milliliters (such as a graduated cylinder)
Experiment Directions

1. Make a table with columns for recording time (in five-second intervals) and the amount of water lost (in ml).
  2. Use the paper clip to punch a hole in the bottom of the paper cup. Cover the hole with your finger.
  3. Fill the cup with water.
  4. Hold the paper cup over the measuring container.
  5. When you are ready to begin timing, uncover the hole so that the water drips into the measuring container.
  6. Record the amount of water in the measuring container at five-second intervals for one minute.
• What is the rate of water dripping in ml per minute?
Answers will vary based on the size of the hole in the cup.
A good approximation of the drip rate is about 8 ml of water every 10 seconds.
• At this rate how much water is lost in a day? A year?
Answers will vary. Example shown for 8 ml of water every 10 seconds.
8 ml of water every 10 seconds
48 ml of water every 1 minute
2880 ml of water every 1 hour
69210 ml of water every 1 day
25,228,800 ml of water every 1 year
• One gallon of water is approximately 3,785 ml. How many gallons of water are wasted as a result of leaks in a year?
25,228,800 ml of water every 1 year
6,665.5 gallon of water every 1 year
• An average shower uses about 17gallons of water. How many showers could be taken in a year if there were no leaky showerhead?
6,665.5 gallon of water every 1 year
392 showers of water every 1 year
Situation A. Ratios, Ratios, and More Ratios!
Examine each ratio application and answer the questions for each.
Free Throws

Two basketball teams recently competed in free throw attempts. Team A made 108 out of 126 attempts. Team B made 195 out of 257 attempts. It is difficult to tell which team was better by looking at the raw numbers. Sid thought it would help to express the raw numbers as percents.

1. Describe how Sid could use percents to decide which team has the best free throw average.
  2. Describe another strategy for deciding which team has the best free throw average.
2020 Census Population Data
The 2020 Census data shows that the population of people in the USA under the age of 18 was 73.1 million in 2020. That is a decline of 1.4% from the 2010 Census.

1. What was the population of people under the age of 18 in 2010?
  2. If the decline of people under the age of 18 continued at this rate, what will be the population in 2030? 2040?
1. Team A
Team B
2. Students could find a unit rate or make one
quantity common to both ratios.
Unit Rates:
Team A-
Team B-
One possible common quantity is the number of attempts made: 108
Team A-
Team B-
One possible common quantity is the number of total free throws:126
Team A-
Team B-
You can also think of this as
73.1 million (the 2020 Census data) x 98.6% = 72.08 million in 2030.
Rising Ocean Levels and Erosion
It is reported that approximately 20 square miles of dry land and wetland were converted to water along the Atlantic Coast between 1996 and 2011.

1. At this rate how much land will be lost between 2011 and 2022?
  2. A small unpopulated island in the Atlantic Ocean is 2000 ft wide by 9,380 feet long. At this rate, how long before the island is submerged?
(Photo credit: https://www.nps.gov/)
Puffins in Alaska
Puffins are a black and white seabird with a flat brightly colored bill. A biologist studies puffins on a remote island off Alaska.
Last summer she trapped 20 puffins, tagged them, and then released them.
This summer she trapped 50 puffins and found that 2 of them were tagged.

1. What percent of the puffins caught this summer were tagged?
  2. Use the biologist’s information to estimate the number of puffins on the island.
(Photo credit: https://www.istockphoto.com/search/2/image?phrase=puffin)
(15 years)/(20 sq.miles)≈ (11 years)/(14.6666… sq.miles)
Students might wright this with sq. miles in the denominator or square miles per year.
2. 2,000 ft • 9,380 ft needs to be changed to miles
(15 years)/(20 sq.miles)≈ (0.5 years)/(0.67 sq.miles)
(2 tagged)/(50 total)≈ (4 tagged)/(100 total)
2. About 500 puffins
(4% tagged)/(20 puffins)≈ (100% tagged)/(500 puffins)
Situation B. What is the Question?
Make up a situation and question that could be solved with each of the following representations.
Answers will vary.

For the proportion the situation and question should reflect that the original ratio is 16 to 120 and that the 120 is being scaled down to 40 so they are finding the x that would scale down the 16 the same way.
One example: The recipe for a trail mix is 16 cups of cranberries and 120 cups of granola. If I only have 40 cups of granola how many cups of cranberries do I need?
For the graph their situation and question should relate the ratios 15/10 and 30/20.
One example: If I know that I paid $15 for 10 candy bars and $30 for 20 candy bars, how can I figure out how much it would be for any number of candy bars?
For the table the situation and question should relate at least two of the ratios in the table.
One example: This table represents the number of hours that I worked (top row) and how much money (bottom row) I was paid at my job at the zoo. If I work 28 hours next week how much will I be paid?
For the equation the situation and question should involve a unit rate of .6.
One example: This equation represents how much it costs to buy apples at the local food market. The x is the number of apples, and the y is the total cost. How much would it cost for 20 apples?
Describe some situations that you encounter in your daily life that require proportional reasoning?
Answers will vary based on students’ experiences.
In this Unit and in prior Units we have been exploring problem situations that require proportional reasoning.
What does it mean to reason proportionally?
Emerging Mathematical Ideas
Understand that proportional reasoning is about making comparisons, using multiplicative thinking instead of additive thinking.
Identify strategies for comparing quantities: ratio tables, equivalent ratios, scaling, and percent.
Begin to formalize the process of setting up proportions and solving for an unknown value.
Understand that to compare ratios you must relate the same two quantities in the same order: part-to-part or part-to-whole.
Reflections on the Mathematical Practices
As we worked on the Problems in this Investigation, we used prior mathematical knowledge to make sense of them. We also applied Mathematical Practices to solve the Problems. For example,
Jayden described his group’s strategy for Problem 1.1 in the following way:
Our group scaled down each recipe to find how much water is needed for 1 cup of concentrate.
For A, we need 1 cup concentrate for 3/2 cups of water.
For B, we need 1 cup concentrate for 9/5 cups of water.
For C, we need 1 cup concentrate for 2 cups of water.
For D, we need 1 cup concentrate for 5/3 cups of water.
The recipe with the least amount of water for 1 cup of concentrate is the most orangey. It is Recipe A.

In this Unit and in prior Units we have been exploring problem situations that require proportional reasoning.
What does it mean to reason proportionally?
Emerging Mathematical Ideas
Recognize and analyze proportional statements.
Broaden understanding that proportional reasoning uses multiplicative thinking instead of additive thinking, and can be used to make decisions and solve problems.
Notice that:

• proportional reasoning is about making comparisons: part-to-part and part-to-whole
  • Rates are a type of ratio
  • Unit rates can be helpful in solving problems
  • Unit rate or constant of proportionality can be found in tables, graphs, and equations
Reflections on the Mathematical Practices

As we worked on the Problems in this Investigation, we used prior mathematical knowledge to make sense of them. We also applied Mathematical Practices to solve the Problems. Think back over your work, the ways you thought about the Problems, and how you used Mathematical Practices.

In Problem 2.1, our group used two different methods. In the first method we doubled the cost of 10 pizzas to find the cost of 20 pizzas at Royal Pizza. In the second method we found the cost of 1 pizza at Royal. Then we multiplied that unit rate by 20 to find the cost of 20 pizzas. Both methods gave the same answer. We agreed that both methods work and both used ratios.
1st Strategy:
2nd Strategy.

Bill made a rate table and a graph for the adult chimp mix in Problem 3.3. He said that the information in the table matched the information in the graph. Mary claimed that 2/3 was the unit rate for the mix according to the graph. She said that the mix contained 2/3 cup of high-protein food or a ratio of 40 cups of high-protein food : 60 cups of high-fiber food.
Both claimed that the graph shows pairs that fit this proportional relationship.
